title: Uganda: Address Lapse in Airport Security
text:
Angola: Angolan President Receives Message From Ugandan Counterpart 
The Daily Monitor expose comes more than a year since the US Embassy in Kampala warned in June 2014 that Entebbe Airport is not safe. 
The amount of money involved in the procurement notwithstanding, it is imperative that police and CAA, mind the security of our country and that of passengers who fly in and out of the country daily. 
Since September 11, 2001, when al-Qaeda terrorists flew into Twin Towers in New York killing more than 3,000 people, security at airports has never been the same. 
Airport officials now stop people at random, search their bags, order them to remove their shoes, and search them. This is the norm at various airport facilities. 
The security at various airports is not an inconvenience to passengers but it is vital for their overall security and many passengers are cooperative. 
Uganda as one of the countries on the terrorists' hit list, should be ahead of the lot in implementing high security measures at its entry and exit ports. 
Bomb screening equipment that is more than two years late, is not a luxury at our airports when terrorists become more sophisticated by day. 
Terrorists are watching how Uganda reacts to new terrorist attempts, looking for weaknesses in our systems to exploit. Entebbe International Airport should not be Uganda's weakest point. CAA and police should put their act together do everything to protect travellers from terrorists, hijackers and other evil people. If anything, airport security measures are the most important function of the airport today. 
Safety is the number one priority of most flyers and if we want a secure country, securing our entry and exit ports is a necessary procedure we should not ignore at any cost. 
Security risks have to be neutralised before they can cause harm. 
The issue: Airport security.
